newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yeltsin to discuss violence blamed on Chechens.
newsitem.headline: Yeltsin to discuss violence blamed on Chechens.

text.p: President Boris Yeltsin is to meet his Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov on Wednesday to discuss a spate of violent incidents in southern Russia blamed on Chechen separatists, Interfax news agency said.
It said the meeting would take place at the Black Sea resort of Sochi where Yeltsin is spending a vacation, but gave no further details.
The situation around Chechnya, where 21 months of war between Moscow troops and rebels ended in a shaky truce in August, has badly deteriorated in the past week.
Russian police fought a brief night skirmish on Tuesday with a group of what they said were 20 Chechen fighters just outside Chechnya, resulting in casualties on both sides.
Two people were killed and more than 20 wounded on Monday in a powerful explosion at the railway station in the southern Russian spa resort of Pyatigorsk.
Kulikov said on Tuesday police had detained two Chechen women fighters suspected of organising the blast.
He told a news conference the two were part of a Chechen armed group which undertook a hostage raid on the Russian town of Budennovsk in 1995 in which more than 100 people were killed.

Russian news agencies quoted police sources as saying the Pyatigorsk attack was similar to a bomb blast at a railway station in the southern Russian town of Armavir last Wednesday which killed two people.
Kulikov demanded tough measures to counteract terrorism.
"These are not rebels. This is not a political struggle," he said. "This is banditry. We will catch and destroy those criminals."

His accusations were immediately denied by Chechen Deputy Prime Minister Movladi Udugov, Itar-Tass news agency said. The separatist leaders accused unnamed Russian special services of planting a bomb to disrupt peacemaking.
Chechen Vice-President Vakha Arsanov, quoted by Interfax news agency, said talks on political matters were impossible until Kulikov apologised for his allegations or proved them.
But the latest tensions seemed to open differences in Moscow over how to handle Chechnya.

Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, speaking at a news conference in the Slovak capital Bratislava, condemned the Pyatigorsk attack but focused on the need to preserve peace talks with the rebels, in contrast with Kulikov's harsh words.

"Terror is vandalism and innocent people die," he said. "But our relations toward the (peace) treaty will not be affected by this...the Chechen leadership has denied any connection with these terrorist attacks."

The August ceasefire halted fighting but did not resolve the main dispute -- whether the rebel region is part of Russia or independent. They two sides are now involved in difficult negotiations over a long-term peace treaty.
Yeltsin's senior aide, Boris Berezovsky, who is heavily involved in shuttle diplomacy with Chechnya, appealed for restraint.
"Irresponsible statements are being made today by those who have not had enough of the war in Chechnya," Interfax news agency quoted him as saying.
Russian news agencies reported that Udugov and Berezovsky, a deputy head of Yeltsin's policy-making Security Council, agreed that peace talks should go ahead.
